This course can be most improved by teaching linearly. While the theme of Mao to Now is appreciated, the lumping of everything post Mao into one era is not only difficult to comprehend, but not conducive to really learning the history. Furthermore, Professor Ho's reading from a manuscript for lecture was too fast and left little clarity on how to navigate critical knowledge from her personal asides. While the course's strength is it's thematic frame, it has a lot left to be desired as far as tangible ways to discuss the theme itself in a logical way.

I did not like the fact that this course was entirely thematic, jumping across two periods. Themes work well when applied to a specific period, but I found it difficult to gain a command of the timeline and figures involved when the material was taught in this non-chronological fashion. 

Additionally, it makes no sense to have a course that meets for 70 minutes twice a week (during which the instructor still solicits student comments and engagement) as well as a discussion section. This course would be better served being taught as a seminar.

I think more use of media, in terms of videos, songs, etc. could be assigned for homework rather than readings. Media was used well in class and added a lot. I also wish we could have discussed contemporary issues in more depth. The class felt more Mao and less now.

I really liked the 'leminar' feel of this course and the emphasis that professor Ho placed on student participation. Lectures were always very well prepared and filled with interesting content, although at times it was hard to write everything down!

One thing that I think could be improved is the percentage grade breakdowns. I think 50% exams is a little too much for a history course, and we perhaps could have done a bigger research paper.

I would take this course Cr/D if anyone was interested. While the history is interesting, the teaching style is not for everyone. As compared to other introductory history courses, this one demands much more work to memorize and learn key passages for IDs on tests. While I am unsure if it was just our TF who had high expectations from us in this history course, overall I would not recommend this course as a fifth nor a fourth unless you really have time to put in the work.

This was a solid survey course in modern Chinese history with a great, accessible professor, and an experienced TF. I would recommend this to anyone looking to have a better cultural understanding of China and why it is how it is today.
Absolutely! I think this is the best introductory course on China at Yale. Essential for the 21st century.

I would, for anyone who wanted to learn more about China's recent history.  I went into the class with very little knowledge on the subject and feel that I have a much greater appreciation of the historical development of the PRC afterwards.

If you're looking to take a course on China, I would recommend it with hesitations. You will definitely learn a lot - sometimes, it feels, a little too much - but it's all important to know. Prof. Ho's lecturing style can be choppy and not coherent, and I often found it difficult to take notes because of that. There were moments when I was studying for midterms/finals that I realized I only had a bullet point or two for keywords, just because they hadn't been fully explained in lecture.
If you're interested in China and want to kind of be treated like a grad student in an undergraduate course, I would definitely recommend this class!
